So I did an audit of the usages of all the renamed exceptions. They are all retriable, and are handled in `JoinGroup`, `SyncGroup`, the heartbeat thread, and during offset commits.

In all cases but one, the operations are retried when they hit a retriable exception, so these should not be returned to the client. 

The one case where the behavior is unclear is in `commitOffsetsAsync()` : https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/trunk/clients/src/main/java/org/apache/kafka/clients/consumer/internals/ConsumerCoordinator.java#L524

I think in this case, the exception is returned to the user. If this true, it seems like we will have to either: 

1. Introduce new error codes and exceptions for the transaction coordinator.
2. Reuse the `GroupCoordinator` errors and exception codes for the transaction coordinator. 

Neither of these is ideal, but seems unavoidable unless I am wrong. 

@ijuma : in the async offsets commit path, am I reading the code wrong? Or are the retriable exceptions really returned to the user?

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk8-scala2.12/2859/
Test FAILed (JDK 8 and Scala 2.12).

I have a PR in parallel to this making heavy modifications to the controller. It converts the controller to a single-threaded model:
https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2816

With that in mind, I feel that:
1. the specific benefit of immutability is somewhat reduced given that we are moving to a single-threaded model.
2. the benefit of more consistent instantiation/updating of controller state is still valid, but we should instead come up with an overall more consistent story for all controller state. For instance, we have a bunch of mutable collection vars in ControllerContext. Sometimes we mutate, sometimes we reassign.

I think the other PR should land soon.
@dguy don't we need to do the same check for the normal KTable too?

Thanks for prompt answer @onurkaraman. Your PR does not change LeaderAndIsr, there should be no conflict, so there is no need to wait for #2816. I cannot agree with 1) and honestly, I am quite surprised that Scala developers here are fine with vars in case classes. I cannot say much about 2) as I have not seen ControllerContext yet.

I think it will be better to do this on top of KIP-86 (PR #2022). A new callback handler can be defined for LDAP without changing `PlainSaslServer`. It will be easy to configure LDAP by specifying a different callback handler.
@guozhangwang yeah it might have an impact on any of the integration tests that use the same applicationId for multiple test methods. I'll update them to set it to true
retest this please

@enothereska For changelogs this will never happen as all key/values that have made it into the changelog will be ok. So restoration is ok. For a `KTable` that is built via `builder.table()` then this may happen, now that i think about it. The `KTableSource` drops null keys, but if it was to be restored it would likely hit the same issue. Thanks!
@dguy (/cc @enothereska): I'd also update the KTable javadocs to cover the null-key behavior/contract.
@ijuma @ewencp would you mind having a look over this for me if you get a chance? thanks
Thanks, LGTM. Included the changes from https://github.com/apurvam/kafka/pull/3 before merging.
Thanks for the PR, LGTM. Merged to trunk after some minor tweaks.

I verified and @jozi-k is correct that this PR does not cause any merge conflicts to #2816. I had a close look and I think it makes the code easier to read, so I am OK with merging it with a few tweaks (https://github.com/jozi-k/kafka/pull/1).

@jozi-k, regarding the comment about mutable case classes, it is understood that it's not a good practice. In reality, `LeaderAndIsr` probably doesn't need to be a case class, so that could be fixed that way too. I think it's important to understand that some of the code in Kafka has been around for a while and is lacking tests. So, we tend to be extra careful when making ad-hoc changes to such code. As a general rule, it's better to think about the end state and then work out the steps to get there.

@ijuma in terms of testing, I'm relying on existing unit, integration, and system tests.

All our PRs already show unit/integration test results, and I provided a link to a passing system test I ran when I first opened the PR.

Thanks for PR @ijuma, I merged it into my branch.
So for the next time, would it be better to also add tests when doing changes like this or you do not want to touch the old code anymore? Or maybe the best thing would be to ask first on dev mailing list and explain what I intend to change and create PR later if I get green light?
Sorry for so many questions, I would like to be involved with Kafka (and Scala) in the future so I am trying to find my way.

A few thoughts:
1. There's no point in changing the old Scala clients (producer and consumer) or any of the code that is only there to support them (Scala request/response classes, MessageSet and related, etc.)
2. For the Controller, it probably makes sense to hold off small refactorings for now while we are fixing some of the architectural issues. Adding tests is fine, but we'd want to figure out a plan for them too.
3. Changes to the rest of the code should be fine although it makes sense to file a JIRA before making larger changes or changes that require some discussion.
4. Picking up an existing JIRA (some of them are marked with the newbie tag) is a good way to get involved.
